I voted yes on the #coronavirus relief bill because so many people in our state needed me to. It is far from perfect, but it will help keep Louisianians healthy & safe, and minimize the disruption caused by the coronavirus.

My full statement ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/3XK7hFZES3

(13/15) Panic and irrational fear are not only totally uncalled for today--they are inconsistent with the faith of any child of God who trusts in His immeasurable love and sovereignty.

As a Christian I'll tell you what I believe...

(11/15) And I would continue to pray for an end to this crisis, for the protection of my congregation, and for the wisdom, safety and discernment of every health care provider and all those in authority. (1 Tim. 2:1-3)

(9/15) Because worship services are the places where we assemble, embrace & share communion & where it is common for older Americans to gather, wisdom suggests we should be careful to protect our people. Louisiana is currently listed in the top 10 states most affected by COVID-19

(7/15) Even though it appears most who contract the illness will ultimately experience only mild symptoms, some seniors & persons with compromised immune systems are at much higher risk. If emergency rooms are full and resources stretched too thin, that will increase their risk.
(6/15) We have to do this to protect our vulnerable populations and ensure that our health care system is not overwhelmed by a rush of newly infected persons.

(5/15) We must remember that the primary reason for the national and state emergency declarations and the public health officials' warnings about large gatherings is to slow, and ultimately stop, the spread of the virus.

(1/15) I've received a number of calls from pastors & constituents around the LA-04 today inquiring about the wisdom & enforceability of the governor's coronavirus proclamation-which, among other things, limits gatherings of 250+ people from now until 4/13 (the day after Easter). https://t.co/zSFjJ4i8Kk
